‘Actor’ obligatorily identified on verb, agreeing in person (1st, 2nd, 3rd), number (singular, dual, plural), and gender (masculine, feminine). ‘Undergoer’ is optionally identified on the verb, by the same agreement markers as the actor agreement markers, and immediately following the actor agreement markers.  The actor and undergoer markers on verbs are the same suffixes as the ‘terminators’ that mark person/number/gender on nouns.

When more than one object occurs, Bruce differentiates between the ‘inner’ object and the ‘outer’ object.  The inner object is the undergoer, and can take verb agreement, while the outer object(s) fill another semantic role, and do not have verb agreement.  The outer objects also do not take case marking, though, like all nouns, they do have a ‘terminator’ expressing person/number/gender.

In attributive noun phrases, the order is usually noun adjective, but is sometimes reversed.  The indefinite marker is always a suffix on the final word of the phrase, regardless of whether this is the adjective or the noun.  When the noun is the phrase is plural, the plural marker attaches obligatorily to the final word of the phrase, and optionally to the other word.  The plural marker also expresses a human/non-human distinction.  When plurality is marked on the adjective, the non-human form is the preferred form, even if the noun of the NP is human.  (§2.1.4)

See notes in Alienability, and log.2-20-05, after consulting Handbook vol. 17 (1996) sketch of Wichita and also comparing Arikara dictionary and Melnar 2004 on Caddo:  I suspect there is no such thing as an NP in this language.  Possessed NP's can be incorporated; body parts seem most prone to this in Caddo, but Parks 1996 illustrates Wichita with kin terms.  Incorporated as S/O, and possessor is raised to object (direct object if incorporated noun is S, dative, with applicative, if it's object -- that's in Caddo; in Wichita, maybe the same but both have applicatives). So I've changed Locus here from 28 (n.d.) to 16 (HH).  (Actually it's HHH: the incorporated noun, the raised possessor, and the applicative.)

True adjectives (small class: colors, ‘big’, ‘small’, ‘old’, and a few others) are suffixed to combining forms of nouns to form noun phrases (p. 12).  Maybe this is juxtaposition; or maybe, since the noun takes the combining form, it is head marking.  Most ‘adjectives’ are stative verb roots that are incorporated into ‘be’; they can be made into participles for attributive use.  These must presumably be dependent marking (the participle agrees in person with the head noun).

There is associative agreement, and agreement is for conjunct person, and the categories in the past tense are Locutor Subject and Locutor Undergoer.  I believe that for most 2-place verb forms at least in the past tense the identity of both subject and object (PO) are likely to be clear in context, so I code everything as double-marked.  However, there is only one person agreement marker per verb form.  Also, this decision is debatable for noun arguments; they are only third person, i.e. non-locutor, so object identity wouldn’t be clear from the verb form.
